results.title: Close harmony
results.brief_description: An inspiring documentation of the work of music teacher Arlene Symons in bringing together a chorus of children from the 1979-1980 class of the Friends School in Brooklyn, New York and the senior chorus from the Council Centre for Senior Citizens, Brooklyn. Three months of separate rehearsals took place, and a pen pal program set up between the two groups. A week before the concert, the groups came together.

results.title: Close-up
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Canal+ and Sacher Film
results.brief_description: Abbas Kiarostami’s (‘The Taste of Cherry’, ‘Through the Olive Trees’) ‘Close-Up’ is part of a remarkable body of films from Iran that address, in very original ways the artifice of cinema and the uneasy junction between life and art. Approached like a documentary, ‘Close-Up’ tells the true story of Hossein Sabzian, an unemployed movie buff who is mistaken for renowned Iranian director Mohsen Makmalbaf (‘Gabbeh’, ‘Moment of Innocence’), and decides to take the misunderstanding further, by deceiving a middle-class Iranian Family. Eventually his fraudulence is exposed and he is faced with a potential jail term. Blurring the line between fact and fiction further is Kiarostami himself who interviews the protagonists involved in this unbelievable story, culminating in Sabzian’s trial which Kiarostami films. Interestingly enough, Makmalbaf (who appears in ‘Close-Up’), has his own freakish experience of truth informing fiction, which became the subject matter for his wonderful film ‘Moment of Innocence’. ‘Close-Up’ also features a short by Italian director Nanni Moretti, called “The Day of the Premiere of ‘Close-Up’”, which pays humorous tribute to Kiarostami and ‘Close-Up’. In Farsi with English subtitles.

results.title: Clone Inc.
results.creator_credit: Karl Parent, Louise Vandelac, Eric Michel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Clone Inc is a critical documentary which discusses the issues of human reproductive technology, particularly the cloning of embryos, and its scientific, psychological and philosophical implications. In its focus on the advocates of human cloning, such as Clone Rights United Front and the religious cult with visions of duplicating their leader’s genes, the Raelians, the program raises numerous questions about the narcissistic fantasies of these groups. Through interviews with and discussions between, among others, biologists, geneticists, a psychoanalyst, and a philosopher the ethical issues crucial to the cloning debate are outlined. The rapid progress of the technology, and the experiments that have already taken place, is also critically engaged with as notions related to a breakdown between the sexes and generational differences, parent-child bond complications and the blurring of individual identities as well as time that are potentially affected by human cloning are posed and debated. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Clint Eastwood: out of the shadows
results.creator_credit: Bruce Ricker, American Masters, BBC-TV and Rhapsody Films
results.brief_description: This documentary on American actor and director Clint Eastwood traces his long career from his early appearances in B-grade films like ‘Tarantula’ (1955) and ‘Return of the Creature’ (1955) and his seven years spent playing the character of Rowdy on the long running television series ‘Rawhide’, to his iconic performances in Leone’s spaghetti westerns and the ‘Dirty Harry’ series. Extensive clips from the films he acted in and directed, are combined with interviews with Eastwood and his contemporaries including Martin Scorsese, James Garner, Janet Maslin, Sergio Leone, Curtis Hanson, William Goldman, Donald Sutherland and Meryl Streep. Influences on Eastwood’s life and career such as his enduring interest in jazz music are also explored. Narrated by Morgan Freeman.

results.title: Cliff hangers
results.creator_credit: Donald Mulholland and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Over a gleaming icefiled and up steep cliffs of bare rock, the camera follows members of the Alpine Club of Canada. Before they set out we are introduced to the climbers’ basic equipment and learn the uses of rope and ice axe. Excitement mounts as the Alpinists leap gaping chasms and drag themselves up sheer walls of rock. At the top, they pause for a view over the sea of mountains surrounding their own vanquished peak. Narrated by Lorne Greene.

results.title: Climbers (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Rosalind Gillespie, Australian Film Commission and Silver Films
results.brief_description: A visually dramatic film which can be used to promote discussion and interest in the art of dance, dance interpretation, choreography and communication. ‘Climbers’ presents an allegory in contemporary dance of the international struggle for women’s liberation, the theme being drawn from the Japanese Women’s ascent of Mount Everest in 1975. An excellent example of contemporary dance in Australia in the 1980’s - Margaret Barr was a significant figure (as a choreographer) of this period and earlier. Film direction by Rosalind Gillespie shows original approach.

results.title: Clean cuisine
results.creator_credit: Mike O'Donnell, John Budd and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Clay Modelling: The Human Face
results.brief_description: The human face in all its expressiveness is shown modelled from inanimate clay. This is a fascinating program for beginners, and for those with some experience, as it is packed with hints and useful information.

results.title: Clay
results.brief_description: Learn the basic techniques of pottery and ceramics and create objects like vases, piggy banks and pots. Highlights basic techniques such as creating a pinch pot, throwing on a wheel and solid construction as well as the art of glazing.
